column4: you might look into LVM.  Which allows you to resize partitions on the fly
Gparted is a program to format stuff.  LVM is a system of partitioning that allows you to shift stuff around later.
shift it around later?
yeah.  If you have 100GB /home and 10 on /, and you find youre running out of space, you can move some /home to /, without even rebooting
oh i see what you mean. is it made for gnome or kde? or independent of both?

it's completely independant.  Here's some more info: http://www-128.ibm.com/developerworks/linux/library/l-lvm/  nice graphics and stuff.  You'll need the alternate CD though, Desktop doesn't have support for it.
obviously, all the compiling and stuff on that page doesn't apply to ubuntu.  But the opening paragraphs explain LVM really well
what other differences are there for the alternate vs normal?
Alternate is a textmode installer, instead of a lvieCD.  You boot up, and go straiht to the installer.  Alternate also has additional options (a GUI-less install, OEM install, etc)

oh, Aternate CD also has a repository on it.  So you get full ubntu install + additional packages without the internet.
